sentence: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 raced to new record highs on Monday after the Senate passed its version of pro-growth tax reform early Saturday morning, clearing the way for US corporations to pay lower federal taxes.

As a result, investors swapped tech stocks for shares of companies that stand the most to benefit from tax reform including Dow components Home Depot ( HD ), Disney ( DIS ) and General Electric ( GE ).

The Nasdaq is underwater for a second straight day as the rotation from chipmakers and FAANG (Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix, Alphabet) stocks causes the Nasdaq to underperform the Dow for a sixth consecutive day.
Economic data contributed to the buoyant tone on Wall Street as factory orders were not as soft as expected.
Orders were down 0.1% in October, but up 0.8% excluding a 4.2% drop in transportation-related orders.
Additionally, September was revised upward from a healthy 1.4% increase to +1.7%, and durable goods orders for October were revised to -0.5% from -0.8%.
European markets were higher in concert with Wall Street, including the UK's FTSE-100, which despite volatility in sterling, closed with a constructive gain of 0.53%.
Sterling was thrown around in a wide range Monday as Brexit negotiations seemed to end without a deal.

The currency snapped back, taking the FTSE off its high after British Prime Minister Theresa May gave assurances that talks will continue this week and will likely result in an agreement with the European Union.
Crude oil was down $0.65 to $57.71 per barrel.
Natural gas was down $0.08 to $2.98 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was down $5.70 to $1,276.60 an ounce, while silver was down $0.06 to $16.32 an ounce.
Copper was up $0.003 to $3.10 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was down 0.94% to $11.56 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was down 2.54% to $5.94.
Among precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was down 0.70% to 22.31 while SPDR Gold Shares were down 0.53% to $120.94.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 0.90% to $15.39.
